{{Coord|50|59|0|N|11|2|0|E|display=inline,title}} | |footnotes = }} The '''Principality of Erfurt''' ({{lang-de|Fürstentum Erfurt}}; {{lang-fr|Principauté d'Erfurt}}) was a small state in modern [[Thuringia]], [[Germany]], that existed from 1807 to 1814, comprising the modern city of [[Erfurt]] and the surrounding land. It was subordinate directly to [[Napoleon]], the [[Emperor of the French]], rather than being a part of the [[Confederation of the Rhine]]. After nearly 3 months of siege, the city fell to [[Kingdom of Prussia|Prussian]], [[Austrian Empire|Austrian]] and [[Russian Empire|Russian]] forces. Having been mainly Prussian territory before the [[Napoleonic Wars]], it was mainly restored to Prussia by the [[Congress of Vienna]]. == Background and establishment == In the wake of the [[French Revolutionary Wars]] and the [[Treaty of Lunéville]], the [[Holy Roman Empire]] underwent a process of substantial territorial reorganisation known as the [[German mediatization]], under which Erfurt, since the 10th century a subject of the [[Electorate of Mainz|Electorate and Archbishopric of Mainz]], was transferred to the [[Kingdom of Prussia]], to compensate for territories Prussia lost to France on the [[Left Bank of the Rhine]].{{Cite web |title=Hauptschluß der ausserordentlichen Reichsdeputation |publisher=documentArchiv.de |url=http://www.documentArchiv.de/nzjh/rdhs1803.html |date=25 February 1803 |accessdate=17 January 2016 |language=de }}{{wikisource-inline|Hauptschluß der außerordentlichen Reichsdeputation vom 25. Februar 1803|single=true}} Fearing the rise in the power of [[Napoleon]]'s [[First French Empire]] after their defeat of [[Austrian Empire|Austria]] and establishment of the French-sponsored [[Confederation of the Rhine]], Prussia and [[Russian Empire|Russia]] mobilized for a fresh campaign, and Prussian troops massed in [[Kingdom of Saxony|Saxony]] as a part of the [[War of the Fourth Coalition]]. The [[Battle of Jena–Auerstedt|twin battles of Jena and Auerstedt]] were fought on 14 October 1806 on the plateau west of the river [[Saale]], between the {{lang|fr|[[Grande Armée]]}} and the forces of [[Frederick William III of Prussia]]. The decisive defeat suffered by the [[Prussian Army]] subjugated Prussia to the French Empire until the [[War of the Sixth Coalition|Sixth Coalition]] was formed in 1812.{{cite book |author=[[David G. Chandler]] |title=The Campaigns of Napoleon |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=hNYWXeVcbkMC |year=2009 |orig-year=First published 1966 |publisher=[[Simon & Schuster]] |isbn=978-1-439-13103-9 |pages=479–506 }} After Jena and Auerstedt, a large number of refugees appeared at the Prussian fortress of Erfurt. At first they were refused entrance, but later the gates were opened and soon the city thronged with at least 12,000 demoralized soldiers. Attempts were made by some officers to return the troops to their regiments, but the men refused to cooperate. [[Joachim Murat]], [[Marshal of France]], sent French Colonel {{Interlanguage link multi|Claude de Préval|fr|3=Claude Antoine Hippolyte de Préval}} into Erfurt under a [[flag of truce]].{{cite book |author=[[Francis Loraine Petre]] |title=Napoleon's Conquest of Prussia 1806 |publisher=[[Lionel Leventhal]] |year=1993 |orig-year=First published 1907 |isbn=1-85367-145-2|pages=194–95 }} The Frenchman demanded an immediate surrender, which the Prussian commandant initially refused. [[Karl August, Grand Duke of Saxe-Weimar-Eisenach|Karl August, Duke of Saxe-Weimar and Saxe-Eisenach]], waited near Erfurt in the hope that large numbers of troops would join the retreat; when few did so, he withdrew toward [[Bad Langensalza|Langensalza]]. Without support from Prussian {{lang|de|[[Generalfeldmarschall]] [[Wichard Joachim Heinrich von Möllendorf|Möllendorf]]}}, collapsed from injuries suffered at Auerstedt, the fortress commandant signed articles of capitulation; included in the terms were the surrender of the [[Petersberg Citadel]] (''{{lang|de|[[:de:Zitadelle Petersberg|Zitadelle Petersberg]]}}'') and large quantities of gunpowder and munitions. Altogether, about 12,000 Prussian and Saxon troops under [[William I of the Netherlands|William VI, Prince of Orange-Nassau]], became prisoners and 65 artillery pieces were captured. At the time of the capitulation, Murat had about 16,000 troops near Erfurt.{{cite book |author=[[Digby Smith]] |title=The Napoleonic Wars Data Book |publisher=Greenhill |year=1998 |isbn=1-85367-276-9 |page=226 }} Historian [[Francis Loraine Petre]] remarked that Erfurt was the first of a series of "pusillanimous capitulations" by Prussian fortress commanders, writing that Napoleon's plans might have been delayed had the city held out for just a few days. Instead, the French emperor was able to immediately launch the entire army after his fleeing enemies. == French rule == [[File:Entrevue Erfurt by Nicolas Grosse.jpg|thumb|''{{lang|fr|L'entrevue d'Erfurt}}'', [[oil painting|oil on canvas]] by [[Nicolas Gosse]], showing the [[Congress of Erfurt]] — [[Napoleon]] (centre) is receiving [[Karl von Vincent|Baron Vincent]], ambassador of [[Austrian Empire|Austria]], (left) with [[Charles Maurice de Talleyrand-Périgord|Talleyrand]] behind the table and [[Alexander I of Russia|Tsar Alexander I]] side-on, to the picture's right.]] [[File:Die Napoleonshöhe im Steiger bei Erfurt von NH Dornheim.jpg|thumb|''{{lang|de|Die Napoleonshöhe im Steiger bei Erfurt}}'', painted by {{Interlanguage link multi|Nikolaus Dornheim|de|3=Nikolaus Christian Heinrich Dornheim}} in 1812. Inaugurated in March 1811 to celebrate [[Napoleon]]'s birthday, this [[Greek Revival architecture|Greek-style]] [[temple]] with grotto, flowerbeds and fountain in the ''{{lang|de|Stiegerwald}}'' was burned in November 1813 and completely destroyed by Erfurters and their [[War of the Sixth Coalition|besiegers]] in 1814.]] Erfurt was administered by a civilian and military Senate{{cite web |url=http://www.erfurter-fuerstenkongress-1808.de/historie.htm |title=Kurzer historischer Überblick |trans_title=Brief historical overview |work=Napoleon's Fürstenkongress Erfurt |publisher=Euratibor |language=German |date= |accessdate=2 January 2016 }} (''{{lang|de|Finanz- und Domänenkammer Erfurt}}''){{cite web |url=http://www.erfurt.de/ef/de/erleben/entdecken/geschichte/chronik/111885.html |title=1806–1814: Erfurt unter französischer Besetzung |trans_title=1806–1814: Erfurt under French occupation |publisher=Erfurt Stadtverwaltung [Erfurt city administration] |language=German |date= |accessdate=2 January 2016 }} under a French governor, based in the {{lang|de|[[:de:Kurmainzische Statthalterei|Kurmainzische Statthalterei]]}}, previously the seat of city's governor under the Electorate. Napoleon first visited the principality on 23 July 1807, inspecting the citadels and fortifications. On 4 August 1807, Napoleon attached the [[Saxe-Weimar]] territory of [[Blankenhain]] and declared the Principality of Erfurt to be directly subordinate to himself as an "imperial state domain" ({{lang-fr|domaine réservé à l'empereur}}), separate from the [[Confederation of the Rhine]] (nominally a French [[protectorate]] set up to replace the now-defunct Holy Roman Empire), which the surrounding [[Thuringia]]n states had joined. On 27 September 1808, Napoleon was ceremonially presented the [[keys to the city]] at the Brühler-Tor before going to meet [[Alexander I of Russia|Tsar Alexander I]] on the road to [[Weimar]] to re-enter the city with the tsar. Between 27 September and 14 October 1808, Napoleon hosted the [[Congress of Erfurt]] in the principality, intended to reaffirm the alliance with Tsar Alexander I concluded the previous year with the [[Treaties of Tilsit]] following the end of the War of the Fourth Coalition. The meeting became a great conference involving an array of kings, princes, dukes, barons and notables from all over Europe, including the kings of [[Kingdom of Saxony|Saxony]], [[Kingdom of Bavaria|Bavaria]], [[Kingdom of Württemberg|Württemberg]] and [[Kingdom of Westphalia|Westphalia]] (the last being Napoleon's brother [[Jérôme Bonaparte|Jérôme]]).{{Cite encyclopedia |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=I55DAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA325 |title=Erfurt |encyclopedia=Allgemeine Militair-Encyclopädie |pages=324–25 |publisher=Webel |year=1869 |accessdate=17 January 2016 |language=de }} The resulting convention recognised the Russian conquests of [[Grand Duchy of Finland|Finland]] from [[History of Sweden (1772–1809)|Sweden]] and the [[Danubian Principalities]] from the [[Ottoman Empire]] and stated that, should France go to war again with [[Austrian Empire|Austria]], Russia should [[wikt:make common cause|make common cause]],{{cite web |url=http://www.napoleon-series.org/research/government/diplomatic/c_erfurt.html |title=The Erfurt Convention |work=The Napoleon Series |date=1995 |accessdate=2 January 2016 }} though the tsar's support in the [[War of the Fifth Coalition]] was minimal.{{cite journal |author=Alexander Mikaberidze |title=Non-Belligerent Belligerent Russia and the Franco-Austrian War of 1809 |journal=Napoleonica. La Revue |year=2011 |volume=1 |issue=10 |pages=4–22 |url=http://www.cairn.info/revue-napoleonica-la-revue-2011-1-page-4.htm |accessdate=2 January 2016 }} During their administration, the French introduced [[street light]]ing and a tax on foreign horses to pay for maintaining the [[road surface]]. The {{lang|de|[[:de:Peterskirche (Erfurt)|Peterskirche]]}} suffered under the French occupation, with its inventory being auctioned off to other local churches — including the [[organ (music)|organ]], [[church bell|bells]] and even the [[steeple|tower]] of the {{lang|la|Corpus Christi}} chapel (''{{lang|de|Fronleichnamskapelle}}'') — and the former monastery's library being donated to the [[University of Erfurt]] (and then to the Boineburg Library when the university closed in 1816). Similarly the [[Cyriaksburg Citadel]] (''{{lang|de|[[:de:Zitadelle Cyriaksburg|Zitadelle Cyriaksburg]]}}'') was damaged by the French with the city-side walls being partially dismantled in the hunt for imagined treasures from the convent, with workers being paid from the sale of the building materials.{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=upBXAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA21 |title=Ruinen oder Taschenbuch zur Geschichte verfallener Ritterburgen und Schlößer (etc.) |trans_title=Ruins, or: A pocketbook on the history of dilapidated knights' castles |author=Gerhard Robert Walter von Coeckelberghe-Dützele |publisher=Mich. Lechner |date=1834 |page=21 |accessdate=23 January 2016 |language=de |quote=''{{lang|de|Nach der unglücklichen Schlacht bei Jena und dem Rückzuge der Preußen, wurde sie durch Kapitulation den Franzosen übergeben, und erhielt anfangs eine ziemlich starke Besatzung; doch wurde sie in der Folge so von ihnen vernachläßigt, daß in einer gewissen Epoche der Marketender Sturm mit seiner Familie und ein alter Unteroffizier ihre ganze Garnison ausmachten. Damals war es, wo der Intendant Devismes und der Domainen-Direktor Gentil in der nach der Stadt zugekehrten Seite der Mauer einen Schatz suchen ließ, der noch aus den Zeiten des ehemaligen Benedektiner-Nonnenklosters hier versteckt seyn sollte, ohne zu bedenken, daß zufolge der oben angeführten, an der Mauer befindlichen Inschrift, kein Schatz von 1478 her in einer Mauer versteckt seyn konnte, die über 100 Jahre darnach erst erbaut worden war; aber die Habsucht eilte hier jeder nähern Untersuchung vor. Bei dieser Gelegenheit wurde auch die alte Burgkapelle demoliert und aus den verkauften Baumaterialien die Arbeiter bezahlt, die beim Schatzgraben hilfreiche Hand geleistet hatten.}}'' [After the unfortunate battle of Jena and the retreat of the Prussians, it was handed over by capitulation to the French, and was initially fairly strongly garrisoned; but was subsequently so neglected that at one time the whole garrison consisted of the [[wikt:sutler|sutler]] Sturm with his family and an old sergeant. At that time, Intendant {{Interlanguage link multi|de Vismes|fr|3=Pierre Jean Louis de Vismes}} and Domain-Director Gentil searched in the city-side walls for treasure hidden since the times of the former Benedictine nunnery — without considering that an inscription located on the wall above showed that it had been built just over 100 years later, so no treasure could have been hidden there in 1478, but greed hastened this before any closer investigation. On that occasion the old chapel was demolished, and the workers who had helped dig for treasure were paid from the sale of the building materials.] }} In 1811, to commemorate the birth of the [[Napoleon II|Prince Imperial]], a {{convert|70|ft|adj=on|abbr=off}} ceremonial [[column]] (''{{lang|de|Die Napoleonsäule}}'') of wood and plaster was erected on the [[common land|common]], on the instigation of the French administration (the ''{{lang|de|Domänenkammer}}'') and funded by the city treasury.{{cite web |url=http://www.thueringer-naturbrief.de/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=97&Itemid=187&limit=1&limitstart=5 |title=Denkmale Erfurts 1806–1814 |trans_title=Monuments of Erfurt 1806–1814 |publisher=Thüringer Naturbrief |language=German |accessdate=3 January 2016 }} Inaugurated on 20 March 1811; it was burned and destroyed by the citizenry on 6 January 1814 when the [[War of the Sixth Coalition|Sixth Coalition]] finally entered the city after over 2 months of siege.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=PnLrCQAAQBAJ&pg=PA25 |title=Die Belagerung von Erfurt 1813–1814 |trans_title=The Siege of Erfurt 1813–1814 |author=Frank Palmowski |publisher=Sutton Verlag |date=2015 |orig-year=First published 2013 |isbn=978-3-954-00604-5 |page=25 |accessdate=17 January 2016 |language=de |quote=''{{lang|de|Preußische Truppen marschieren in der Stadt ein. Auf dem Anger kommt es zu Jubelszenen. Der Napoleon-Obelisk wird zerstört.}}'' [Prussian troops march into the city. On the [[village green]] this leads to scenes of jubilation. The Napoleon obelisk is destroyed.] }} Similarly, the ''{{lang|de|Napoleonshöhe}}'' — a [[Greek Revival architecture|Greek-style]] [[temple]] topped by a [[Winged Victory of Samothrace|winged victory]] with shield, sword and lance and containing a [[bust (sculpture)|bust]] of Napoleon sculpted by [[Friedrich Wilhelm Eugen Döll|Friedrich Döll]]{{cite book |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=PnLrCQAAQBAJ&pg=PA82 |title=Die Belagerung von Erfurt 1813–1814 |trans_title=The Siege of Erfurt 1813–1814 |author=Frank Palmowski |publisher=Sutton Verlag |date=2015 |orig-year=First published 2013 |isbn=978-3-954-00604-5 |page=82 |language=de }} — was erected in the ''{{lang|de|Stiegerwald}}'' woods on the direction of the senate-president (''{{lang|de|Kammer-Präsident}}'') {{lang|de|von Resch}}; the design included a grotto with fountain and flower beds, using a large pond (''{{lang|la|lavoratorium}}'') from the {{lang|de|Peterskirche}}. Inaugurated with ceremony on 14 August 1811 after extravagant celebrations for Napoleon's birthday, with a eulogy on Napoleon being given by Resch to little celebration from the citizenry, the French administration commissioned a painting of the temple from {{Interlanguage link multi|Nikolaus Dornheim|de|3=Nikolaus Christian Heinrich Dornheim}} in 1812, but it was burned on 1 November 1813 and completely destroyed by Erfurters and their besiegers in 1814. The celebrations of Napoleon's birthday were repeated in 1812, with a concert in the {{lang|de|[[Predigerkirche (Erfurt)|Predigerkirche]]}}, conducted by [[Louis Spohr]]. == Siege and fall == [[File:Peterskloster 2.jpg|thumb|The former [[Order of Saint Benedict|Benedictine]] monastery buildings of {{lang|de|Peterskloster}} within the [[Petersberg Citadel]] (''{{lang|de|[[:de:Zitadelle Petersberg|Zitadelle Petersberg]]}}''), as seen from the northeast in 1800. These buildings were damaged in the siege by the [[War of the Sixth Coalition|Sixth Coalition]]; in green is the {{lang|de|[[:de:Peterskirche (Erfurt)|Peterskirche]]}}, blue is the {{lang|la|Corpus Christi}} chapel (''{{lang|de|Fronleichnamskapelle}}'') and red is the Chapel of [[Saint Anne]].]] After his disastrous [[French invasion of Russia|invasion of Russia]], Napoleon briefly rested the remnants of the {{lang|fr|[[Grande Armée]]}} in Erfurt on 15 December 1812, on their way back to France proper. With the [[War of the Sixth Coalition|Sixth Coalition]] forming after French defeat in Russia, on 24 February 1813 Napoleon ordered the Petersburg Citadel to prepare for [[siege]], visiting the city on 25 April to inspect the fortifications, in particular both Citadels. The French authorities banned all burials in city cemeteries from 26 June 1813, setting up a single central cemetery in {{lang|de|Johannesplatz}}, an arrangement that continued until 9 December 1816 after the city had been restored to Prussia. After the imposition of martial law on the [[Petersberg Citadel]] in 1813, the {{lang|de|Peterskirche}} was used as a warehouse and the {{Interlanguage link multi|counts of Gleichen|de|3=Gleichen (Adelsgeschlecht)}} were reburied in [[Erfurt Cathedral]].{{cite book |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=PnLrCQAAQBAJ&q=Gleichen |title=Die Belagerung von Erfurt 1813–1814 |trans_title=The Siege of Erfurt 1813–1814 |author=Frank Palmowski |publisher=Sutton Verlag |date=2015 |orig-year=First published 2013 |isbn=978-3-954-00604-5 |pages=16, 73 |language=de |quote=''{{lang|de|... Gruft der Grafen von Gleichen in der Peterskirche öffnete man am 19. August 1813 und überführte den Grabstein zum Dom.}}'' [... Tomb of the Counts von Gleichen in the {{lang|de|Peterskirche}} to be opened on 19 August 1813 and transferred the gravestone to the Cathedral.] }} On 10 July 1813, Napoleon put in charge of the defences of Erfurt brigadier general {{Interlanguage link multi|Alexandre d'Alton|fr}}, [[nobility of the First French Empire|baron of the Empire]]. However, when the French decreed that 1000 men would be conscripted into the {{lang|fr|Grande Armée}}, the recruits were joined by other citizens in rioting on 19 July that led to 20 arrests, of whom 2 were [[capital punishment|sentenced to death]] by French [[court-martial]]; as a result, the French ordered the closure of all inns and alehouses.{{cite book |editor=Willibald Gutsche |title=Geschichte der Stadt Erfurt |trans_title=History of the city of Erfurt |edition=2nd revised |language=German |location=Weimar |year=1989 |isbn=3-7400-0095-3 |postscript=. }} Cited within {{lang|de|[[:de:Belagerung von Erfurt (1813)|Belagerung von Erfurt (1813)]]}} on the ''[[German Wikipedia]]''. With the Sixth Coalition's decisive [[battle of Leipzig|victory at Leipzig]] (16–19 October 1813), French troops head to Erfurt; Napoleon visited on 23 October, Erfurt being his only major weapons and storage depot east of the Rhine.{{cite book |author=Karl Bade |title=Napoleon im Jahre 1813 : politisch-militairisch geschildert, Band 4 |trans_title=Napoleon in the year 1813: the political and military situation described, volume 4 |location=Altona |publisher=G Blatt |year=1841 |page=234 |oclc=16891036 |postscript=. }} Cited within {{lang|de|[[:de:Belagerung von Erfurt (1813)|Belagerung von Erfurt (1813)]]}} on the ''[[German Wikipedia]]''. Within a week of Leipzig, however, Erfurt was besieged by Prussian, Austrian and Russian troops under the command of Prussian Lt Gen [[Friedrich Graf Kleist von Nollendorf|von Kleist]].{{cite book |author=[[Christoph Wilhelm von Koch]] |title=Histoire abrégée des traités de paix entre les puissances de l'Europe depuis la paix de Westphalie, Volume 3 |trans_title=Abridged history of the peace treaties between the powers of Europe since the Peace of Westphalia, Volume 3 |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=7lw_AAAAcAAJ&pg=PA303 |publisher=Meline, Cans et Compagnie |year=1838 |language=French |quote=''{{lang|fr|Le général Kleist assiégeait Erfurt. Par suite d'une capitulation signée le 20 décembre, le générale français d'Alton se retira dans les deux forts de Petersberg et Cyriacsbourg, et la ville fut remise aux Prussiens le 6 janvier 1814.}}'' [General Kleist laid siege to Erfurt. As a result of a capitulation signed on 20 December, the French general d'Alton withdrew to the two forts of Petersberg and Cyriaksburg, and the town was handed over to the Prussians on 6 January 1814.] }} Coalition shelling of the Petersberg Citadel on 6 November caused substantial damage to districts to the north of the cathedral and the destruction of much of the monastery buildings and the {{lang|de|Peterskirche}}. After a capitulation signed by d'Alton on 20 December 1813 the French troops withdrew to the two fortresses of Petersberg and Cyriaksburg, allowing for the Coalition forces to march into Erfurt on 6 January 1814 through the {{lang|de|Schmidtstedter}} Gate, to jubilant greetings;{{cite web |url=http://www.erfurt.de/ef/de/erleben/entdecken/geschichte/chronik/111888.html |title=1814–1850: Erfurt im preußischen Staat |trans_title=1814–1850: Erfurt in the Prussian state |publisher=Erfurt Stadtverwaltung [Erfurt city administration] |language=German |date= |accessdate=3 January 2016 }}{{citation |author=Georg Friedrich Hühn |title=Kurzgefasste Nachricht von der Belagerung, Blokade und Einzug der Königlich Preußischen Truppen in Erfurt. Vom 21sten Oktober 1813 bis zum 8ten Januar 1814. In einem Briefe als ein Journal abgefasst, und an einen vertrauten Freund abgesendet. Bei Gelegenheit der 25jährigen Jubelfeier neu abgedruckt |trans_title=Concise news of the siege, blockade and entry of the Royal Prussian troops into Erfurt. From 21 October 1813 to 8 January 1814. In a letter as a journal written and sent to a trusted friend. Reprinted on the occasion of the 25th jubilee |location=Erfurt |year=1839 |postscript=. }} Cited within {{lang|de|[[:de:Belagerung von Erfurt (1813)|Belagerung von Erfurt (1813)]]}} on the ''[[German Wikipedia]]''. the ''{{lang|de|Napoleonsäule}}'' ceremonial column was burned and destroyed as a symbol of the citizens' oppression under the French. After a call for volunteers 3 days later, 300 Erfurters joined the Coalition armies in France. Finally, in May 1814, the French capitulated, with 1,700 French troops vacating the Petersberg and Cyriaksburg fortresses. During the two and a half months of siege, the mortality rate rose in the city greatly; 1,564 Erfurt citizens died in 1813, around a thousand more than the previous year. After the [[Congress of Vienna]], Erfurt was restored to [[Kingdom of Prussia|Prussia]] on 21 June 1815, becoming the capital of one of the three districts (''{{lang|de|Regierungsbezirke}}'') of the new [[Province of Saxony]], but some southern and eastern parts of Erfurter lands joined Blankenhain in being transferred to the [[Grand Duchy of Saxe-Weimar-Eisenach]] the following September. Although enclosed by [[Thuringia]]n territory in the west, south and east, the city remained part of the Prussian [[Province of Saxony]] until 1944. == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == Further reading == * {{cite book |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=phFscAAACAAJ |title=Festung in Thüringen: Zitadelle Petersberg, Zitadelle Cyriaksburg, Festung Heldrungen |trans_title=Fortresses in Thuringia: Petersberg, Cyriaksburg and Heldrungen |author= |publisher=General Books LLC |date=2010 |isbn=978-1-158-97132-9 |language=de }} * {{cite book |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=OSI6SQAACAAJ |title=Die Citadelle Petersberg zu Erfurt | trans_title=The Petersburg Fortress in Erfurt |author=Robert Huth |publisher=Mitteilungen des Erfurter Geschichtsvereins [Erfurt Historical Society] |date=2009 |orig-year=First published 1908 |isbn=978-3-86777-069-9 |language=de }} * {{cite book |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=R-LiAAAAMAAJ |title=Erfurt, Napoleon und Preussen 1802 bis 1816 |trans_title=Erfurt, Napoleon and Prussia, 1802 to 1816 |author=Klaus-Dieter Kaiser |publisher=Verein für die Geschichte und Altertumskunde von Erfurt [Society for the History and Archaeology of Erfurt] |date=2002 |isbn=978-3-980-71887-5 |language=de }} * {{cite book |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=n1nzXwAACAAJ |title=Das Fürstentum Erfurt und die Herrschaft des grossen Kaisers: Leben und Sterben in bewegter Zeit; (1806–1814) |trans_title=The Principality of Erfurt and the reign of the great Emperor: Life and death in turbulent times (1806–1814) |author1=Horst Moritz |author2=Marina Moritz |publisher=Museum für Thüringer Volkskunde [Museum of Thuringian Folklore] |date=2006 |language=de }} * {{cite book |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=NV-1bS_iF_AC |title=Die Belagerung von Erfurt. Ihre Spuren 1813 bis 2013 |trans_title=The Siege of Erfurt and its traces 1813 to 2013 |author=Frank Palmowski |publisher=Sutton Verlag |date=2013 |isbn=978-3-95400-252-8 |language=de }} {{Client states of the Great French War}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Erfurt, Principality of}} [[Category:History of Erfurt|Principality Of Erfurt]] [[Category:Former states and territories of Thuringia]] [[Category:Client states of the Napoleonic Wars]] [[Category:1806 establishments in Europe]] [[Category:1814 disestablishments in Europe]]
